TextBlock._LCLZText: Applies a user-defined heat load to one or more bodies, to define the heat source(s) that impact adjacent bodies.

The heat load can be assigned as a total value, or on a per-unit volume basis. Internal heat load attributes assigned in the Electronics workspace are copied, automatically, to the electronics cooling study. Adjustments made in the electronics cooling study are not reflected back in the Electronics workspace.

Tips._LCLZText: Select one or more bodies where the load will be placed.

Description._LCLZText:
Only Internal Heat load types are supported.
Click Change Heat Units to specify a unique unit for this Load.
Toggle Unit Volume to allow per-unit volume assignment.

Tips._LCLZText: Select one or more bodies where the load will be placed.

Description._LCLZText:
Only Internal Heat load types are supported.
Click Change Heat Units to specify a unique unit for this Load.
Toggle Unit Volume to allow per-unit volume assignment.

TextBlock._LCLZText: Calculates the ability of the heat sink to dissipate heat and reduce the temperature of electronic bodies, based on its geometry and material properties.

Create an idealized representation of the heat sink design, automatically, to reduce analysis time while maintaining an accurate result. The geometric properties used in the idealization are obtained from the as-modeled device.
Applies a volumetric air or fluid flow to a body, such as a fan that blows air through an enclosure.
Simplify complex fan geometries, automatically, to reduce the analysis time while maintaining an accurate result. Air flow is propagated to the volume around the adjacent electronic bodies.

Tips._LCLZText: Select all the bodies that represent a single fan. For the analysis the fan is simplified, as symbolically represented by the green prismatic cylinder superimposed on your model during the Forced Flow load setup. For each selection of multiple bodies, the resulting simplified green cylinder represents a single fan. Change the flow direction using the Direction Type.

Description._LCLZText: You can window select multiple fan bodies. Edit or Delete Forced Flow settings from the Fan item in the Browser.

Tips._LCLZText: Select all the bodies that represent a single fan. For the analysis the fan is simplified, as symbolically represented by the green prismatic cylinder superimposed on your model during the Forced Flow load setup. For each selection of multiple bodies, the resulting simplified green cylinder represents a single fan. Change the flow direction using the Direction Type.

Description._LCLZText: You can window select multiple fan bodies. Edit or Delete Forced Flow settings from the Fan item in the Browser.

TextBlock._LCLZText: View the temperature of electronics bodies and the air surrounding them, that results from applied heat loads.

Hide non-critical bodies and create slice planes through the model, to study the temperature of critical bodies. Identify bodies at risk, or above their critical temperatures. Change the scale to highlight temperatures above a certain value.
Applies a user-defined maximum safe operating temperature to specified bodies, to provide an indication of when the body may malfunction or fail.

Bodies are not required to have a critical temperature. Where a critical temperature is defined, bodies operating above the critical temperature are displayed as At Risk. Critical temperature attributes assigned in the Electronics workspace are copied, automatically, to the electronics cooling study. Adjustments made in the electronics cooling study are not reflected back in the Electronics workspace.

Tips._LCLZText: View and edit the critical temperature settings on each body.

Description._LCLZText:
When a critical temperature is defined, any body operating above the critical temperature are displayed as At Risk in the Results view. The maximum temperature across a body is reported as its operating temperature.

All bodies participate in the solve, however not all bodies are required to have a critical temperature.

Critical temperature attributes assigned in the Electronics workspace are copied, automatically, to the electronics cooling study. Adjustments made in the electronics cooling study are not reflected back in the Electronics workspace.

TextBlock._LCLZText: Shows how likely a PCB body is to exceed its critical temperature and overheat.
To create this result, set the Critical Temperature on bodies of interest during the study set up. Only bodies with a critical temperature assigned to them are shown in this view.
Shows the internal temperatures of bodies, as well as the temperature and velocity of the air surrounding them.

Create section planes to view the internal temperatures of bodies. Move and rotate the section planes along the plane to identify the best location for them. Switch between air temperature and air velocity.
Shows the temperature of all model bodies, such as PCB bodies, boards, and enclosures, that fall within the range of interest.
Use the Range of interest slider on the legend to alter the temperature at which bodies are included in this view.
